instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN: What is P5VS4RS3_EN? PP5VS4RS3_EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. When you see _EN in front of a signal name, it means that it is enabling whatever comes before the _EN when the signal is high..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>, green light OK, no FAN spin.
threads.message:
Hi guys,

I started a new thread as the one similar to my problem is.. ehmmm similar which can lead to a messed up existing thread. So here is exactly what happens to mine:

It came with LD but almost impossible to notice. I did a UC but nothing changed.

1) Green -> Orange Light OK
2) 3V42, PPBUS, PPVRTC, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> OK
3) SMC seems alive, various lines produce pulses, voltages are there, there is 32KHz clock going in, maybe I need to check something more specific?
4) SPI looks and feels good
5) <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> missing => <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> also missing

Also it does not start with <CAPACITOR>C1300</CAPACITOR> & <CAPACITOR>C1303</CAPACITOR> removed.

Thank you in advance,

g

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>, green light OK, no FAN spin.
threads.message: Are the probe points to the left/down from the SPI ROM looking clean? A break there is common since it is along the edge.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>, green light OK, no FAN spin.
threads.message:
Also the signal side of <RESISTOR>R1303</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1302</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R1301</RESISTOR>, and <RESISTOR>R1300</RESISTOR> never drop below 3v, right? I had one where <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> was 2.9v, just for the f of it i shorted one of the 3.3v ones next to it to <SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> and it turned on and worked forever..

but this can be anything. PCH issue, corroded trace around BIOS, SMC keeping <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> low, 

Is <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> plain 0v dead, or jumping up and down?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>, green light OK, no FAN spin.
threads.message:
Hi louis, guys,

I checked the resistors you mentioned and all are at 3.2+ but I found a corroded pad beside the BIOS chip for line <SIGNAL>SPI_CS0_L</SIGNAL> which I bridged but still no fan spin. I also checked surrounding pads but there is continuity.

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> looks dead, not jumping up&down.

you think this broken line (<SIGNAL>SPI_CS0_L</SIGNAL>) could have corrupted the BIOS? is a re-flashing attempt worth it?

apologies for the long delay between responses.


EDIT: weird behaviour detected. After plugging in the charger a few times the light went GREEN->off (instead of ORANGE) and the fan started spinning and the CPU got hot. Repeating the procedure with the magsafe adapter makes the light go Green -> Orange and no fan spin. A few tries later fan spin again. Then nothing... Any clues?

EDIT2: <SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> also missing.. maybe irrelevant?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>, green light OK, no FAN spin.
threads.message: Look where that signal goes to on both sides and see if something is corroded further down.
